titleStmt.title: Fixed-Time Synchronization of Complex Networks with Impulsive Effects via Non-Chattering Control

analytic.title: Fixed-Time Synchronization of Complex Networks with Impulsive Effects via Non-Chattering Control

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TAC.2017.2691303, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Dealing with impulsive effects is one of the most challenging problems in the field of fixed-time control. In this paper we solve this challenging problem by considering fixedtime synchronization of complex networks (CNs) with impulsive effects. By designing a new Lyapunov function and constructing comparison systems, a sufficient condition formulated by matrix inequalities is given to ensure that all the dynamical subsystems in the CNs are synchronized with an isolated system in a settling time which is independent of the initial values of both the CNs and the isolated system. Then, by partitioning impulse interval and using convex combination technique, sufficient conditions in terms of linear matrix inequalities are provided. Our synchronization criteria unify synchronizing and desynchronizing impulses. Compared with existing controllers for fixed-time and finite-time techniques, the designed controller is continuous and does not include any sign function, and hence the chattering phenomenon in most existing results is overcome. An optimal algorithm is proposed for the estimation of the settling time. Numerical examples are given to show the effectiveness of our new results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: D URING the past decade, much attention has been at- tracted to the dynamical behaviors of complex networks (CNs) [1]. The main reason is that many real systems can be described as CNs, such as the internet networks, epidemic spreading networks, collaborative networks and social networks [2], [3], etc. A typical character of a CN is that it is composed of a large number of interconnected dynamical nodes and has "small-world" or "scale-free" property. Synchronization is an important collective behavior in CNs and has attracted extensive attention in the past few decades [4]- [14]. Generally speaking, synchronization in a network means that the states of all coupled dynamical systems tend to a common state as the network evolves. Synchronization has important applications in various disciplines such as information processing [15], secure communication [16]. Asymptotic synchronization was considered in [17], [18], [19]. Recognizing the importance of convergence rate for the performance of synchronization, many researchers investigated exponential synchronization of CNs [20], [21], which is a special case of asymptotic synchronization. However, most of existing results on asymptotic and exponential synchronization can be guaranteed only when time approaches to infinity. Since the life span of biologies and apparatus are limited, asymptotic and exponential synchronization criteria are actually not applicable in practice. In order to enhance convergence, another kind of synchronization called finite-time synchronization has been proposed and widely studied in recent years [22]- [31]. Finite-time synchronization implies that synchronization can be achieved in a desired time called settling time. When the initial values of all the nodes are known, one can design some effective controllers with tunable parameters, by which the considered synchronization can be realized before a settling time given in advance. Obviously, based on finitetime techniques, the efficiency of image processing and secure communication will be greatly improved. Moreover, compared with asymptotic control, finite-time control exhibits several other advantages such as better robustness and disturbance rejection [24], [30].

It should be noted that the settling time of finite-time techniques is heavily dependent on the initial values of considered systems, which makes the settling time not fixed for different initial values. Moreover, not all the initial values of the systems are available in practice. These drawbacks prohibit the practical application of finite-time techniques. Recently, a special finite-time approach called fixed-time control is proposed in [32]. The advantage of fixed-time techniques over classical finite-time ones is that its settling time is not dependent on the initial values. Therefore, the settling time of fixed-time techniques can be completely determined by the parameters of a closed-loop system. Based on the framework of fixedtime techniques, some new control schemes are established and several new results are obtained in [33]- [40]. Especially, several kinds of fixed-time consensus are studied in [35]- [37]; fixed-time (cluster) synchronization of CNs was considered in [38] and [39]; fixed-time derive-response synchronization of Cohen-Grossberg neural networks with delays was investigated in [40]. From the view point of practical applications, results in [35]- [40] essentially improve classical finite-time results.

It is worth mentioning that the sign function is indispensable for the controllers in [35]- [40]. It is well known that the sign function always introduce chattering phenomenon to the system state and controls signals [30], which damages equipment and induces undesirable effects. Actually, in previous investigations, the sign function plays an important role in synchronizing and stabilizing linear and nonlinear systems when finite-time (or even fixed-time) problems are considered. In the literature, various attempts have been done to eliminate chattering when finite-time approach is considered. For instance, a controller based on a discontinuous function under integration is designed in [41]. However, the controllers in [41] are complex and difficult to be implemented in practice. Recently, a simple controller without the sign function and integration is proposed in [42] to synchronize a class of CNs in finite time, but the controller in [42] is still discontinuous. A natural question arises: Can we design continuous controllers without the sign function by which finite-time and fixedtime synchronization be realized? This paper gives a positive answer to the question.

An inevitable phenomenon in the process of signal transmission is that signals may be suddenly changed at some discrete time instants [42], [43]. That is, the controlled network may exhibit impulsive effects [43]- [50]. The effects of impulses may facilitate synchronization (synchronizing impulses), or cause harm to synchronization (desynchronizing impulses), or neither facilitate nor prevent synchronization (inactive impulses). There are a large body of literature concerning exponential synchronization of CNs with impulsive effects. For instance, the authors in [50] studied exponential synchronization of networks with heterogeneous impulses, the authors of [51] considered outer synchronization of CNs via pinning impulsive controllers. Based on the concept of "average impulsive interval", synchronization of CNs with synchronizing and desynchronizing impulses was studied under a unified framework in [45] and [46]. Recently, considering the advantages of finite-time techniques, the authors in [42] investigated finite-time synchronization for a class of CNs with synchronizing and desynchronizing impulses based on the framework of average impulsive interval. Nevertheless, the controllers in [42] are discontinuous and the analytical techniques cannot be extended to fixed-time synchronization. On the other hand, the synchronization criteria obtained by using the analytical method proposed in [42] cannot be expressed in linear matrix inequalities (LMIs) since they are based on the 1-norm. Actually, most of existing results concerning finite-time and fixed-time synchronization are not derived by LMI approach. It is reported that, compared with non-LMI methods, LMI techniques lead to less conservative criteria [52]. Moreover, criteria in terms of LMIs can be easily checked by using standard commercial software. To the best of our knowledge, fixed-time synchronization with impulsive effects has not been considered in the literature, let alone the same problem considered by using the LMI technique. The main difficulty lies in that, if classical methods are utilized, the impulsive effects are not easy to be dealt with in studying fixed-time synchronization. The present paper aims to solve this challenging problem.

Motivated by the above discussions, this paper aims to synchronize each state of coupled nodes in a class of CNs with impulses with an isolated dynamical system within a fixed time. The coupling configuration matrix is general and is not assumed to be symmetric. By partitioning the interval of impulses, using convex combination technique, and constructing comparison systems through special transforms, the difficulty of dealing with the impulsive effects is overcome. The main contributions are as follows: 1) It is the first time that fixedtime synchronization of CNs with impulses is considered, the algorithm of the settling time is optimized, where impulse interval is restricted by a pair of lower and upper bounds; 2) Unlike classical fixed-time or finite-time controllers as those in [35]- [40] and [42], the designed controllers are continuous and do not involve the sign function, which can be easily implemented in practice without inducing chattering; 3) Sufficient conditions formulated by LMIs are established to guarantee the fixed-time synchronization, which unify synchronizing and desynchronizing impulses. Results of this paper essentially extend those in [42]. Moreover, our results show that non-LMI result cannot ensure the fixed-time synchronization when the impulses are desynchronizing. An optimal algorithm is given to estimate the settling time.

Notations: N + denotes the set of positive integers. I denotes the identity matrix with compatible dimension as determined by context. R n denotes the Euclidean space, and R n×m is the set of all n × m real matrices. The spectral norm of A is denoted as A = λ max (A T A), where the superscript T denotes transposition. The symmetrization of A is denoted by
div.formula: A s = 1 2 (A + A T ). A > 0 (A < 0) means that A is positive (negative) definite. C = diag(c 1 , c 2 , . . . , c n ) means C is a diagonal matrix.
div.p: The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, the model of CNs with impulses is presented and some necessary assumptions and lemmas are given. In Section III, several fixed-time synchronization criteria are developed. Then, in Section IV, illustrative examples and their simulations are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the theoretical analysis. Finally, in Section V, conclusion is given. II. PRELIMINARIES Consider a CN consisting of N identical nodes described as follows:
div.formula: ẋi (t) = Ax i (t) + Bf (x i (t)) + N j=1 u ij Φx j (t) + R i (t),(1)
div.p: where i ∈ N = {1, 2, . . . , N }, x i (t) = (x i1 (t), x i2 (t), . . . , x in (t)) T ∈ R n represents the state vector of the ith node, A, B ∈ R n×n are known constant matrices, f (•) ∈ R n is a nonlinear function. The Laplacian matrix U = (u ij ) N ×N describes the linear coupling configuration of the network, in which element u ij is defined as this: if there is a link from node j to node i, then u ij > 0(i = j), otherwise,
div.formula: u ij = 0, u ii = - N j=1,j =i u ij , i ∈ N . Φ is inner coupling matrix, R i (t)
div.p: is control input to the ith node. We assume that the Laplacian matrix U is irreducible, which means that the digraph of the network is strongly connected. The initial value of the network (1) is
The aim of this paper is to derive conditions for ensuring the synchronization of all the states of the nodes in network (1) with the manifold
div.formula: x 1 (t) = x 2 (t) = • • • = x N (t) = z(t), where z(t) = (z 1 (t), z 2 (t), . . . , z n (t)) T ∈ R n is defined as ż(t) = Az(t) + Bf (z(t))(2)
div.p: with initial value z(0) = z 0 . z(t) can be any desired state: equilibrium point, a nontrivial periodic orbit, or even a chaotic orbit. More precisely, our synchronization goal is defined as follows.

Definition 1: The complex network ( 1) is said to be globally synchronized with (2) within a fixed time, if there exists T which is independent of the initial value x i0 , z 0 , i ∈ N , such that lim t→T x i (t)z(t) = 0 and x i (t)z(t) ≡ 0 for t ≥ T , i ∈ N . Here, T is called the settling time.
Denote e i (t) = (e i1 (t), e i2 (t), . . . , e in (t)) T = x i (t)z(t), i ∈ N , and construct the following controllers:
div.formula: R i (t) = -ξ i e i (t) -αe m h i (t) -βe p q i (t), i ∈ N ,(3)
div.p: where α > 0, β > 0, m, h, p, q are positive odd integers satisfying m > h, p < q, ξ i ≥ 0, e θ i (t) = (e θ i1 (t), e θ i2 (t), . . . , e θ in (t)) T , θ = m h or p q . We assume that there is at least one i 0 ∈ N such that ξ i0 > 0. In this paper, the transient time of signal from the network to the controller, which may cause transmission delay, is not considered.

Remark 1: The controller ( 3) is continuous and does not include the sign function. It is well known that the sign function always introduces a chattering effect to the systems' state and control signals. In the literature, the use of the sign function is indispensable for the controllers in studying finite-time and fixed-time problems [22]- [40]. In this paper, without using the sign function in the controller, fixed-time synchronization will be investigated. Note that fixed-time synchronization is a special case of classical finite-time synchronization, and hence, the results of this paper improve the corresponding ones in [22]- [40].

Considering the fact that, in the process of signal transmission, the states e i (t), i ∈ N , may be suddenly changed at some discrete time instants which can be well described as a differential equation with impulses [42], [43], we consider the following controlled CN with impulsive effects:
div.formula:      ẋi (t) = Ax i (t) + Bf (x i (t)) + N j=1 u ij Φx j (t) -ξ i e i (t) -αe m h i (t) -βe p q i (t), t = t k , ∆x i (t k ) = d k i e i (t - k ), t = t k ,(4)
div.p: where
div.formula: d k i is a constant, the time sequence {t k , k ∈ N + } denotes the impulsive instants, ∆x i (t k ) = x i (t + k ) -x i (t - k ), x i (t + k ) = lim t→t + k x i (t), x i (t - k ) = lim t→t - k x i (t). Without loss of generality, assume x i (t k ) = x i (t + k ).
div.p: Note that the impulsive gain d k i depends on both the node i and the impulsive instant t k , which means that the impulsive effect on the synchronization can be different from node to node and may be nonidentical at different impulsive instants [50].
Subtracting (2) from ( 4), it follows from the continuity of z(t) that
div.formula:      ėi (t) = Ae i (t) + Bg(e i (t)) + N j=1 u ij Φe j (t) -ξ i e i (t) -αe m h i (t) -βe p q i (t), t = t k , e i (t k ) = (1 + d k i )e i (t - k ), t = t k ,(5)
div.p: where g(e i (t
div.formula: )) = f (x i (t)) -f (z(t)). Remark 2: When |1 + d k i | < 1, we have e i (t k ) < e i (t - k ) . Hence the impulse sequence with |1 + d k i | < 1 is synchronizing. Since |1 + d k i | > 1 means that e i (t k ) > e i (t - k ) , the impulse sequence with |1 + d k i | > 1 is desyn- chronizing. Similarly, when d k i = -2 or d k i = 0, we have e i (t k ) = e i (t - k )
div.p: , and hence, the impulse sequence with d k i = -2 or d k i = 0 is inactive to the synchronization [42], [45], [46]. It should be note that, at any time instant t k , some nodes in the CN (4) may be subject to synchronizing impulses, and some nodes can be subject to desynchronizing impulses, and the others may have inactive impulses. Therefore, the impulses considered in this paper are general.
For convenience, let e(t)

div.formula:      ė(t) = (A + U -Ξ)e(t) + BG(e(t)) -αe m h (t) -βe p q (t), t = t k , e(t k ) = D k e(t - k ), t = t k ,(6)
div.p: where the initial value of the error system is e(0) = e 0 = (e T 10 , e T 20 , . . . , e T N 0 ) T , e i0 = x i0z 0 , i = 1, 2, . . . , N . According to Definition 1, synchronizing CN (1) with ( 2) within fixed time is equivalent to stabilizing the zero solution of error system (6) in a fixed time.

The following assumptions are needed in our study. Assumption 1: f (•) is a Lipschitz function with constant L. Assumption 2: The impulse sequence {t k , k ∈ N + } belongs to D(τ min , τ max ) {t 0 < t 1 < . . . , < t k < . . . , lim k→+∞ t k = +∞, τ min ≤ t kt k-1 ≤ τ max }, where τ min < τ max and τ min , τ max are positive constants.

Let ̺(s, t) be the number of impulsive times on the time interval (s, t), then a time sequence {t k , k ∈ N + } belonging to D(τ min , τ max ) satisfies t-s τmax -1 ≤ ̺(s, t) ≤ t-s τmin . Lemma 1: [53]. Let ξ 1 , ξ 2 , . . . , ξ n ≥ 0, 0 < p ≤ 1, q > 1.
Then the following two inequalities hold:
div.formula: n i=1 ξ p i ≥ n i=1 ξ i p , n i=1 ξ q i ≥ n 1-q n i=1 ξ i q .

div.head: III. FIXED-TIME SYNCHRONIZATION OF THE CN
div.p: In this section, sufficient conditions are derived to guarantee fixed-time synchronization given in Definition 1, which unify synchronizing, inactive, and desynchronizing impulses. We first give a general criterion formulated by matrix inequalities with time-varying parameters, then a specific criterion in terms of LMIs is established by constructing the time-varying parameters in detail. Two corollaries are provided to demonstrate that the LMI results can surely reduce the conservatism of synchronization criterion and lead to ideal result which non-LMI methods are unable to derive.
The following expressions will be extensively used:
div.formula: ᾱ =αλ 1 (N n) h-m 2h λ -h+m 2h 2 , β =βλ 1 λ -p+q 2q 2 , T 1 (ᾱ, β) = 2hτ max (h -m) ln µ ln 1 - µ h-m 2h ln µ 2 ᾱτ max + 2qτ max (q -p) ln µ ln 2 βτ min 2 βτ min -µ p-q 2q ln µ , T 2 (ᾱ, β) = h ᾱ(m -h) + q β(q -p)

div.p: Consider the following system for comparison purpose:

Compared ( 16), ( 17) with (18), one can see that 0 ≤ V (t) ≤ η(t). Consequently, if there is T > 0 such that η(t) ≡ 0 for t > T , then V (t) ≡ 0 for t > T . Hence, to prove the fixed time stability of the error system (6), we only need to prove the corresponding problem of the zero solution of system (18). It is obtained from (18) that, for t ∈ (t k-1 , t k ), η(t) is strictly decreasing. Hence, η(t) is strictly decreasing on [0, +∞) if 0 < µ ≤ 1. When 0 < µ ≤ 1 and η(t - k ) > 1, the value of η(t k ) may be larger or smaller than 1. Since η(t) is strictly decreasing and 0 < µ ≤ 1, there exists t k0 ∈ N + such that η(t - k0 ) ≤ 1, then η(t) ≤ 1 for t ∈ [t k0 , +∞). Similarly, if there exists t ∈ (t k0-1 , t k0 ) such that η( t) ≤ 1, then η(t) ≤ 1 for t ∈ [ t, +∞).
Let r = η h-m 2h when η ≥ 1. It can be seen from ( 18) that r(0) → 0 when η(0) → ∞, and r(t) → 1 for η(t) → 1. Thus,

div.p: for 0 ≤ η < 1. Since q > p, it follows that r(t) → 1 when η(t) → 1, and r(t) → 0 when η(t) → 0. Therefore,

Now the global stability within fixed time of the zero solution of (18) has been transformed to the two problems: (i) the solution of ( 19) approaches to 1 in a fixed time and (ii) the solution of (20) approaches to 0 in a fixed time. More precisely, if r(t) of ( 19) reaches 1 from 0 in a fixed time T 1 and r(t) of ( 20) reaches 0 from 1 in a fixed time T 2 , then, from any initial value η(0), η(t) → 0 in the fixed time T 1 + T 2 . We shall consider the above (i) and (ii) in three cases: 0 < µ < 1, µ = 1, and µ > 1.
Case 1: 0 < µ < 1. In this case, one has μ > 1 and 0 < μ < 1.

div.p: Next we consider the case η(t - k ) ≥ 1 and η(t k ) < 1. In this case, the time interval of η(t) > 1 approaching 1 is obviously smaller than T 1 and the time interval of 0 < η(t) < 1 approaching 0 is obviously smaller than T 2 . Hence, combining ( 23) and ( 25), one has that, for any initial value e 0 , the error system (6) can be stabilized to 0 in T 1 + T 2 , that is, when 0 < µ < 1, the CN ( 1) is globally synchronized with (2) within the fixed time T 1 (ᾱ, β).
Case 2: µ = 1. It can be observed that μ = μ = 1 and obtained from ( 21) that

div.p: Therefore, when µ = 1, the CN ( 1) is globally synchronized with (2) in the fixed time T 2 (ᾱ, β).

Based on the previous discussions, it is obtained that, for any initial value η(0) > 0, there is a fixed time T which is independent on η(0) > 0, such that lim t→T η(t) = 0 and η(t) ≡ 0 for t ≥ T . Since e(t) ≤ 1 λ1 V (t) ≤ 1 λ1 η(t), one has lim t→T e i (t) = 0 and e i (t) ≡ 0 for t ≥ T . By Definition 1, the controlled CN (1) is globally synchronized with (2) within fixed time T . The proof is completed Remark 3: When µ > 1, it follows that μ > 1 and μ̺(0,t) -q-p q β t 0 μ̺(s,t) ds ≤ μ t τ min -q-p q β τmax ln μ μ t τmax -1 + q-p q β μ-1 τmax ln μ . Since τ min < τ max , the right-hand side of the inequality approaches to infinity as t → +∞, hence it cannot be guaranteed that there exists a finite time T 2 such that r(t) of ( 20) approaches to 0 from 1. Note that µ ≤ 1 does not mean that |1 + d k i | ≤ 1, i ∈ N , k ∈ N + , since the P (t - k ) and P (t + k ) satisfying ( 7)-( 8) may not be identical. That is, Theorem 1 gives a unified fixed-time synchronization criterion for the CNs with synchronizing, desynchronizing, and inactive impulses. Note that finite-time synchronization criteria in [42] are obtained independently according to synchronizing, desynchronizing, and inactive impulses. On the other hand, the restrictive condition µ ≤ 1 implies that, for given impulsive sequence with constraint on impulsive interval, the absolute value of impulsive gains for desynchronizing impulses cannot be too large. This observation is different from that in [42], which says that the number of consecutive impulses with minimum impulse interval of the desynchronizing impulse sequence should not be too large. Results of this paper and [42] demonstrate the restrictive conditions of impulsive effects on finite-time synchronization from different aspects.

Remark 4: From the proof of Theorem 1 one can understand the rationale behind the designed controller (3). When α = β = 0, it is found from (12) that V (t) ≤ θ T (t)Ω(t)θ(t) ≤ λ max (Ω(t))e T (t)e(t), where λ max (Ω(t)) < 0. Hence, the part -ξ i e i (t) in the controller (3) aims to synchronize the CN asymptotically. When V (t) > 1, the part -αe m h i (t) plays a 0018-9286 (c) 2016 IEEE. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TAC.2017.2691303, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control 6 major role which controls the CN such that V (t) = 1 in a fixed time. When V (t) ≤ 1, the part -βe p q i (t) works such that the value of the V (t) approaches to zero in a fixed time.

The time-varying variables ζ(t) and P (t) in Theorem 1 make the fixed-time synchronization criterion more general. However, due to the time-varying variables ζ(t) and P (t), it is difficult to solve the matrix inequalities ( 7) and ( 8), which restrict its practical applications. In what follows, a special method is proposed to construct ζ(t) and P (t) such that the fixed-time synchronization criterion is easy to be verified.
Given a positive integer H, we divide the interval [t k , t k+1 ) into H + 1 parts [54], [55]. Denote t k,ρ = t k + ρτ min /H, where ρ = 0, 1, 2, . . . , H -1. Then we have t k,0 = t k and
div.formula: t k,H = t k + τ min . Let S k,ρ = [t k,ρ , t k,ρ+1
div.p: ). When t ∈ S k,ρ , define matrix function
div.formula: P (t) = P (t k,ρ + σM ) = (1 -σ)P ρ + σP ρ+1 = P ρ (σ),
div.p: where P ρ , ρ = 0, 1, 2, . . . , H -1, are positive definite matrices, σ = (tt k,ρ )/M , M = τ min /H. It follows that 0 ≤ σ ≤ 1 and σ = 1/M = H/τ min . When t ∈ [t k,H , t k+1 ), the matrix function P (t) is fixed as a positive definite matrix P H . It can be found that, for k ∈ N + ,
Similarly, for positive constants
div.formula: ζ ρ , ρ = 0, 1, 2, . . . , H, define ζ(t) = (1 -σ)ζ ρ + σζ ρ+1 = ζ ρ (σ) for ρ = 0, 1, 2, . . . , H -1. Let ζ(t) = ζ ρ (σ), t ∈ S k,ρ , ζ H , t ∈ [t k,H , t k+1 ).
div.p: It follows that there exist positive constants ω, ǫ such that P (t) ≥ ωI nM , ζ(t) ≥ ǫ for t ≥ 0. The following result is obtained by using the above specific time-varying variables ζ(t) and P (t) and convex combination technique.

Theorem 2: Suppose that Assumptions 1 and 2 are satisfied. For given 0 < µ ≤ 1 and positive integer H, if there are positive definite diagonal matrices P ρ ∈ R N n×N n , positive constants ζ ρ , ρ = 0, 1, 2, . . . , H, such that, for ρ = 0, 1, 2, . . . , H -1, the following LMIs hold:
div.formula: Σ ρ = Π ρ P ρ B * -ζ ρ I N n < 0,(26)
Σ ρ+1 = Π ρ+1 P ρ+1 B * -ζ ρ+1 I N n < 0,(27)
Σ H = Π H P H B * -ζ H I N n < 0,(28)
div.p: -µP
where
div.formula: Π ρ = 2[P ρ (A+U -Ξ)] s +ζ ρ L 2 I N n + H τmin (P ρ+1 -P ρ ), Π ρ+1 = 2[P ρ+1 (A + U -Ξ)] s + ζ ρ+1 L 2 I N n + H τmin (P ρ+1 - P ρ ), Π H = 2[P H (A + U -Ξ)] s + ζ H L 2 I N n .
div.p: Then, under controller (3), there is a fixed time after which the network (1) is synchronized with (2). Moreover, the settling time is estimated as (i) T 1 (ᾱ, β) when 0 < µ < 1; (ii) T 2 (ᾱ, β) when µ = 1, where λ 1 = min{λ min (P ρ ), ρ = 0, 1, . . . , H}, λ 2 = max{λ max (P ρ ), ρ = 0, 1, . . . , H}.
Proof: For ∀k ∈ N + , consider Lyapunov function

div.p: The rest of the proof is the same as that in the proof of Theorem 1. This completes the proof.

Remark 5: In Theorem 2, the value of µ plays a key role in estimating the fixed time T . Besides given, one can also obtain the value of µ through the following procedure. Set positive integer H and solve the LMIs ( 26)-( 28) first to derive P 0 and P H , then solve the optimization problem: max µ s.t. (28).
The following corollary can be directly obtained from Theorem 1.
Corollary 1: Suppose that Assumptions 1 and 2 are satisfied. If there are scalars 0 < µ ≤ 1, ζ > 0, and positive definite diagonal matrix P ∈ R N n×N n such that
div.formula: Ω = Ω P B * -ζI N n < 0,(36)

where Ω = 2[P (A+U -Ξ)] s +ζL 2 I N n . Then, under controller (3), there is a fixed time after which the network ( 1) is synchronized with (2). Moreover, the settling time is estimated as (i) T 1 (ᾱ, β) when 0 < µ < 1; (ii) T 2 (ᾱ, β) when µ = 1, where λ 1 = λ min (P ), λ 2 = λ max (P ).
The following criterion is not in LMI form, which has no free parameter and is easy to be verified.

div.p: Define function Φ(ζ) as follows:
div.formula: Φ(ζ) = 2λ max ((A + U -Ξ) s ) + ζL 2 + ζ -1 B 2 2 .
div.p: In order to find the optimal solution ζ such that (40) holds, we only need to find a point ζ 0 such that Φ(ζ 0 ) takes the minimum value and Φ(ζ 0 ) < 0. By simple computation, one has that Φ(ζ) takes the minimum value at ζ 0 = B /L. Φ(ζ 0 ) < 0 leads to the inequality (38). Hence, the proof is completed.

Remark 6: The impulses satisfying Theorem 2 can be synchronizing, inactive, and desynchronizing, while the impulses satisfying Corollaries 1 and 2 can only be synchronizing and inactive. These comparisons demonstrate that results obtained from LMIs are more general than those obtained by non-LMI methods. It should be noted that, when the network size N is very large, solving these LMI conditions needs a long time. Hence, Theorems 1 and 2 are not practical for networks with large size.

Remark 7: One can see that if there is µ 0 satisfies (29), then any (29) holds for any µ > µ 0 . It is found from Theorem 2 that the smaller value of µ, the more precision of the estimation of the settling time. On the other hand, for given τ min , τ max , and µ, the settling time in Theorem 2 depends on the values of λ 1 and λ 2 . It is found from ( 14) and ( 15) that larger value of λ1 λ2 leads to more accurate estimation of the settling time. Hence, an optimal algorithm is given as follows: (i) For given 0 < z < 1, suppose there exist positive consists ̺ ρ , ρ = 0, 1, . . . , H, such that P ρ -̺ ρ I nN < 0 and z̺ ρ I nN -P ρ < 0;
(iii) z 0 = max 0<z<1 {z : (26)-( 29) and ( 41) hold with µ 0 };
(V) Use the P ρ , ρ = 0, 1, . . . , H, obtained by solving step (iii) to compute the settling time according to the value of µ 0 .

div.head: IV. NUMERICAL EXAMPLES
div.p: In this section, one numerical example with both synchronizing and desynchronizing impulses is given to illustrate the theoretical results obtained in this paper. Moreover, the issue of reducing the conservatism of Theorem 2 is discussed in Remark 8.
Consider a network with Chua's circuits [56], where n

The network obeys the scale-free distribution of the Barabási-Albert (BA) model [57]. The parameters in the process are constructed as follows: initial graph is complete with m 0 = 10 nodes, m = 3 edges are randomly added in the network when a new node is introduced in, and the final number of nodes is N = 20. Fig. 1 shows the BA scalefree network. If there is a link from node j to node i, then u ij = 1(i = j), otherwise, u ij = 0.

By simple computation, it is derived that Assumption 1 is satisfied with L = 2. The impulse sequence is constructed according to Remark 3 in [58] by taking ǫ = 0.04, N 0 = 2, T a = 0.05. Hence, Assumption 2 is satisfied with τ min = 0.04, τ max = 0.06. solution when H = 1. Moreover, by numerical computation, increasing the value of H can reduce the conservatism of Theorem 2. On the other hand, with the same parameters given in the example, the LMI (36) has no feasible solution, which implies that Theorem 2 is less conservative than Corollary 1.

div.head: V. CONCLUSIONS
div.p: Fixed-time synchronization for a class of CNs with synchronizing and desynchronizing impulses has been considered by a unified method in this paper. The designed controller is continuous and does not include the sign function, which eliminates the chattering phenomenon. Several sufficient conditions are derived by designing time-varying Lyapunov functions, dividing impulse intervals, and using convex combination technique. The main results are formulated by matrix inequalities, which can be easily verified by using standard commercial software. Numerical examples are given to show the effectiveness of our new results.
Pinning technique is a useful control scheme for synchronization of CNs [7]. Moreover, time delays are unavoidable for real networks. Studying fixed-time synchronization of CNs

div.p: This work was jointly supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) under Grant no. 61673078, and HKU CRCG 201511159067, and Research Grants Council of Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under Grants CityU 11204514 and CityU 11300415. X. Yang and Z. Feng are with the School of Mathematical Sciences,

Xinsong Yang received the B.S. degree in mathematics from Huaihua Normal University, Hunan, China, in 1992, and the M.S. degree in mathematics from Yunnan University, Yunnan, China, in 2006. From 2006 to 2012, he was with Honghe University, Honghe State, Yunnan. He is currently a professor with the Department of Mathematics, Chongqing Normal University, Chongqing. He serves as a reviewer of several international journals. He is the author or co-author of more than 70 papers in refereed international journals. His current research interests include collective behavior in complex dynamical networks, multiagent system, chaos synchronization, control theory, discontinuous dynamical systems, and neural networks. He is an Associate Editor of Neural Processing Letters.
